metadata.title: Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) Calculator | MAP Calculator
metadata.description: Calculate mean arterial pressure (MAP) instantly using systolic and diastolic values. A clean, mobile-first tool for fast hemodynamic assessments.
metadata.keywords: MAP calculator, mean arterial pressure calculator, blood pressure tool, hemodynamics, critical care calculator

calculator.reference: Typical adult MAP ranges between 60 and 100 mmHg to sustain adequate organ perfusion.
calculator.lowMap: MAP below 60 mmHg suggests inadequate perfusion and warrants urgent reassessment.
calculator.normalMap: MAP between 60 and 100 mmHg falls within the normal physiologic range.
calculator.highMap: MAP above 100 mmHg may reflect elevated vascular resistance or uncontrolled hypertension.
calculator.disclaimer: Education only. Not a substitute for clinical judgment or professional medical advice.
calculator.professionalNotice: Designed for licensed medical professionals, supervised trainees, and allied health teams.
calculator.emergencyNotice: If this is an emergency, call your local emergency number immediately.

home.title: MAP Calculator
home.description: Instantly compute mean arterial pressure to support bedside hemodynamic decisions.
home.bannerTitle: Education tool – not a medical directive
home.bannerSubtitle: Use only as a clinical reference alongside your professional judgment.
home.bannerItem1: Not medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment
home.bannerItem2: Consult qualified clinicians before acting on results
home.bannerItem3: Emergency situations require immediate emergency services
home.whatIsMapContent: Mean arterial pressure (MAP) is the average arterial pressure across a single cardiac cycle and reflects the driving force that pushes blood through the vascular system.
home.howToCalculateContent: MAP is derived from systolic and diastolic blood pressure readings. Because the heart spends more time in diastole, the diastolic value carries twice the weight of systolic pressure in the standard formula.
home.formulaExplanation: Weighting diastolic pressure captures the longer relaxation phase of the cardiac cycle, producing a stable estimate of perfusion pressure.
home.clinicalSignificanceContent: Maintaining MAP within the target range safeguards tissue perfusion and guides interventions in anesthesia, critical care, and emergency medicine.
home.lowMapDescription: Low MAP (<60 mmHg): risk of organ hypoperfusion and potential shock.
home.normalMapDescription: Normal MAP (60-100 mmHg): supports adequate perfusion in most adult patients.
home.highMapDescription: High MAP (>100 mmHg): may signal increased cardiac workload or hypertensive crises.
home.whenToUseContent: Use MAP when you need a concise view of perfusion pressure to align treatment plans across teams.
home.useCase1: Assessing shock states or sepsis bundles in critical care.
home.useCase2: Guiding vasoactive titration during anesthesia or procedural sedation.
home.useCase3: Monitoring hypertensive emergencies or end-organ protection.
home.useCase4: Evaluating fluid responsiveness and perfusion goals in trauma resuscitation.
home.emergencyContent: If you suspect a medical emergency, call the emergency services in your region (for example 911) or go to the nearest emergency department.
home.resultsDisclaimer: MAP outputs are estimates. Individual patient responses vary and require comprehensive evaluation.
home.targetAudienceProfessional1: Licensed physicians and advanced practice providers
home.targetAudienceProfessional2: Registered nurses, paramedics, and allied health professionals
home.targetAudienceProfessional3: Medical and nursing students under licensed supervision
home.targetAudienceRestricted1: Self-diagnosis or self-directed treatment by the general public
home.targetAudienceRestricted2: Situations requiring urgent or emergent medical care
home.clinicalJudgment1: Compare calculated MAP against bedside findings and full clinical context.
home.clinicalJudgment2: Resolve discrepancies using your professional training and institutional protocols.
home.clinicalJudgment3: Document supporting evidence when incorporating calculator outputs into care plans.
home.privacyContent: We do not collect, store, or transmit personal health data. All calculations run directly in your browser so your entries remain on your device. Basic, anonymized analytics may be used to understand feature usage and keep the tool reliable.
home.termsContent: By using this tool you agree it is provided "as is" for educational reference. It is not a substitute for professional medical judgment. You are responsible for verifying results before applying them in clinical practice.
home.contactContent: Questions or feedback? Reach out to the site administrator at support@mapcalculator.org.
home.updatedNotice: Medical standards evolve quickly; review updates regularly.
home.howToCalculateStepsIntro: Follow these evidence-based steps to compute mean arterial pressure using any pair of systolic and diastolic readings taken in the same session.
home.howToCalculateStep1: Capture systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) from a reliable monitor or arterial line.
home.howToCalculateStep2: Multiply the diastolic value by two to represent the longer diastolic phase of the cardiac cycle.
home.howToCalculateStep3: Add the systolic value to the doubled diastolic value.
home.howToCalculateStep4: Divide the total by three: MAP = (SBP + 2 × DBP) ÷ 3.
home.howToCalculateStep5: Compare the resulting MAP against the clinical ranges (low <60 mmHg, normal 60–100 mmHg, high >100 mmHg) alongside patient-specific factors.
home.howToCalculateExampleContent: For SBP 120 mmHg and DBP 80 mmHg: (120 + 2 × 80) ÷ 3 = 93.3 mmHg. Use this value with trend data and bedside findings before adjusting care.
home.howToCalculateTip: Tip: Ensure readings are in millimeters of mercury (mmHg) and taken under consistent positioning to reduce variability.
home.reference1: Whelton PK, Carey RM, Aronow WS, et al. 2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA guideline for the prevention, detection, evaluation, and management of high blood pressure in adults. Hypertension. 2018;71(6):e13–e115.
home.reference2: Evans L, Rhodes A, Alhazzani W, et al. Surviving Sepsis Campaign: international guidelines for management of sepsis and septic shock 2021. Intensive Care Med. 2021;47(11):1181–1247.
home.reference3: Saugel B, Vincent J-L, Wagner JY. Personalized blood pressure management in critically ill patients. Intensive Care Med. 2020;46(9):1704–1712.
home.reference4: Cecconi M, De Backer D, Antonelli M, et al. Consensus on circulatory shock and hemodynamic monitoring. Intensive Care Med. 2014;40(12):1795–1815.

disclaimer.title: Medical Disclaimer
disclaimer.description: Understand how to interpret and safely apply MAP Calculator outputs.
disclaimer.intro: MAP Calculator is an educational decision-support reference for trained healthcare teams. Using this site does not create a clinician-patient relationship and should never delay or replace in-person medical care.
disclaimer.educationContent: The calculator and accompanying explanations are intended solely for medical education, simulation, and professional reference. They are not comprehensive medical resources and should not be used as the lone basis for diagnosis or treatment.
disclaimer.noAdviceContent: Nothing on this site constitutes medical advice, diagnosis, treatment recommendations, or care plans. Always seek the guidance of qualified physicians and follow institutional protocols before acting on any calculated value.
disclaimer.emergencyContent: If you believe you or someone else is experiencing a medical emergency, call your local emergency number (for example 911) or go to the nearest emergency department without delay.
disclaimer.audienceList1: Licensed medical professionals (physicians, advanced practice providers)
disclaimer.audienceList2: Registered nurses, paramedics, respiratory therapists, and allied health teams
disclaimer.audienceList3: Medical or nursing trainees under the supervision of licensed clinicians
disclaimer.audienceExclusionList1: Members of the general public seeking self-diagnosis or self-treatment
disclaimer.audienceExclusionList2: Use as a substitute for comprehensive clinical evaluation
disclaimer.audienceExclusionList3: Decisions made without consultation from qualified healthcare professionals
disclaimer.clinicalJudgmentContent: Calculator outputs support—but do not replace—clinical reasoning. If results conflict with the patient’s presentation or your expertise, defer to professional judgment, institutional guidelines, and peer consultation.
disclaimer.accuracyContent: While we strive for accuracy, medical evidence evolves rapidly and may render information incomplete or outdated. Verify calculations and recommendations against up-to-date guidelines, pharmacology references, and peer-reviewed literature.
disclaimer.liabilityContent: To the fullest extent permitted by law, the site owners, contributors, and affiliates disclaim liability for any injuries, losses, or decisions arising from the use of this site, inability to use the site, reliance on its outputs, or perceived inaccuracies.
disclaimer.noRelationshipContent: Using this calculator does not establish a medical, legal, or professional relationship with the site owners or contributors. Always engage directly with licensed clinicians for patient-specific care.
disclaimer.thirdPartyContent: Links to external resources are provided for convenience. We do not endorse or control third-party content and are not responsible for its accuracy or privacy practices.
disclaimer.complianceContent: Users are responsible for ensuring their use of this calculator complies with all applicable laws, professional standards, privacy requirements, and licensing regulations in their jurisdiction.
disclaimer.updatesContent: We may update this disclaimer as clinical standards, regulations, or site features evolve. Continued use signifies acceptance of the latest version.
disclaimer.contactContent: For questions about this disclaimer, email support@mapcalculator.org.

privacy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy.description: Understand how MAP Calculator handles data and protects your privacy.
privacy.intro: We designed MAP Calculator to operate completely within your browser so you retain full control of your health data.
privacy.dataCollectionContent: We do not collect, store, or transmit the systolic or diastolic values you enter. All calculations run locally on your device and are never shared with our servers.
privacy.analyticsContent: We may use privacy-friendly analytics to observe aggregate usage patterns, such as page views and device types. These analytics never contain personal identifiers.
privacy.cookiesContent: The site does not set tracking cookies. Your browser may cache assets to improve performance, which you can clear at any time.
privacy.thirdPartiesContent: If we embed third-party resources (for example fonts or analytics), they are selected for their privacy posture. Any future additions will be documented here.
privacy.changesContent: We may update this policy to reflect product changes or legal requirements. Significant updates will be clearly communicated on this page.
privacy.contactContent: Reach out at support@mapcalculator.org for questions about privacy.

terms.title: Terms of Service

terms.intro: By accessing MAP Calculator you agree to the terms described below. Please read them carefully.
terms.acceptableUseContent: Use the calculator for educational or informational purposes only. Do not attempt to reverse engineer, disrupt, or overload the service.
terms.medicalDisclaimerContent: MAP Calculator does not provide medical advice. Always consult qualified clinicians before making diagnostic or treatment decisions. You remain responsible for verifying results.
terms.limitationsContent: The tool is provided "as is" without warranties of accuracy or availability. We may modify or discontinue the service without notice.
terms.liabilityContent: We are not liable for damages arising from the use or inability to use this tool. Use is at your own risk.
terms.changesContent: We may update these terms periodically. Continued use after changes take effect constitutes acceptance of the new terms.
terms.contactContent: Have questions about these terms? Email support@mapcalculator.org.
